In the Age of #BodyPositivity, Is Facetune Setting Us Back?

It’s all over our Instagram feeds, but Facetune’s ease of use sets an unattainable standard that could be damaging to our mental health.

Maddy O
Mar 14

It seems like everyone is using it these days, from the Kardashians to the girls from your school who show up periodically on your Instagram feed. Facetune has become a massive phenomenon in photo-editing culture, offering many of the same functions as Photoshop in an easy-to-use app format. But, with the body positivity movement growing in support, could Facetune be setting us
back?

Many users — including celebrities and models like James Charles — advocate using Facetune as a totally harmless, even beneficial, way to improve your selfies. Say you’re in the middle of a breakout — no biggie, just airbrush those pimples away! You can whiten your teeth, make your lips seem a little larger, your waist a little smaller… but it’s all in good fun, right? Nothing wrong with
showing your best self to the world. Most of us already use small tricks — playing with lighting, angles, filters or makeup — to subtly improve the way we look. Facetune might just be one of those little ways to boost self esteem, fix those minor imperfections which tend to dampen our
confidence.

Besides, everyone’s doing it.

But that may just be the issue. Sure, covering a few blemishes here or there might not be that big of a deal, but when everyone starts posting edited pictures with flawless skin, a new standard of beauty is set. Now, it almost feels like it’s unacceptable to be seen with anything less than perfect
features — even models like Chrissy Teigen have weighed in, calling out an online culture of insanely unattainable beauty standards.

This isn’t to say that all Facetune users should be shamed or demonised, quite the opposite — shaming a behaviour that comes from a place of insecurity will only ever make the issue worse. But, when it comes to online influencers like Instagram models, makeup artists and celebrities, there should be some responsibility given for the impact their image has on an increasingly
younger audience.

We’ve all seen seven year olds on Instagram, and yes, they do tend to be massively cringe-inducing, but spare a moment to think about the world they’ll be growing up in — saturated in artificial perfection, with very few role models who look like, well, actual human people.

You probably won’t be to surprised to learn that the widespread practice of selfie editing on social media has already had disturbing impacts on teens’ body image — as this confronting photo project shows. Just as the generation before ours compared itself to photoshopped supermodels on magazines, today’s kids will grow up in a world where everyone they encounter online uses the same kinds of techniques to perfect themselves. And that’s a scary prospect.

Some prominent Facetune users have publicly discussed the impacts the app has had on them, and it’s not pretty (not even in airbrushed form). Danielle Mansutti, a British-Australian Youtuber and online influencer, released a video discussing her experience with Facetune, and how it changed how she saw herself.

She describes becoming gradually more obsessed with tweaking
every part of her body, refusing to post a photo until she had curated a ‘perfected’ image of herself. Eventually, she says, she stopped recognising these images of herself — they had become that removed from her natural appearance. Now, having realised the negative psychological impact this had on her, she is an outspoken critic of Facetune, warning of the danger it poses, especially to teens and children.

Some have gone so far as to speculate on how Facetune might be linked to BDD (Body Dysmorphic Disorder). BDD is a body-image disorder, characterised by obsessions with imagined or minor ‘flaws’ in appearance, associated with low self esteem. In its most severe forms, BDD can
interfere with social activities as those affected become avoidant in fear of criticism, and has been linked with anxiety, depression, and eating disorders.

It’s easy to see how a culture surrounding the removal of all signs of physical imperfection could lead to a rise in young people affected by preoccupations with their flaws. After all, if all you ever see are digitally perfected versions of beauty, it only gets harder to see natural beauty in yourself. Even the most minor of imperfections — a pimple, some body hair — become unacceptable.

It’s gotten to the point where it isn’t hard to find news articles about teens going to extreme lengths, like getting plastic surgery, to look more like their selfies — but sure, it’s totally harmless.

To its credit, Facetune may have benefits for some members of the trans community, whose dysphoria could be alleviated by seeing themselves with the masculine or feminine features they identify with. Especially for those who want to but can’t undergo hormone therapy, this is one way
to lessen the psychological stress of gender dysphoria.

But, this is probably the minority of cases. On the whole, we as a society need to do a lot more to address how we portray beauty. As the ideal becomes narrower and increasingly unattainable, it will take some brave people to show themselves as they are to change those standards.

So, next time you consider editing a selfie before posting it, consider what message that sends about beauty. True beauty is not perfection. True beauty is authenticity and confidence, and these things don’t need Facetune — just a change in attitude.

Madeleine is a regular columnist for the Minds in Tune blog. She specialises in writing about the discourses that shape our society and how we live. Later in the month, she’ll be exploring the historical attitudes surrounding gender and mental health as part of our Women’s History Month feature.

Keep up with the blog to read more of Madeleine’s articles, and catch new episodes of Minds in Tune every Saturday in your preferred podcast app. For more Minds in Tune content, check out our posts from @mindsintune on most social media platforms.
